QAPair.Question: What is (are) Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) ?
QAPair.Answer: Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) is a rare blood disorder in which the body's immune system produces antibodies that destroy red blood cells. It occurs when the person is exposed to cold temperatures.

QAPair.Question: What causes Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) ?
QAPair.Answer: PCH only occurs in the cold, and affects mainly the hands and feet. Antibodies attach (bind) to red blood cells. This allows other proteins in the blood (called complement) to also latch on. The antibodies destroy the red blood cells as they move through the body. As the cells are destroyed, hemoglobin, the part of red blood cells that carries oxygen, is released into the blood and passed in the urine. PCH has been linked to secondary syphilis, tertiary syphilis, and other viral or bacterial infections. Sometimes the cause is unknown. The disorder is rare.

QAPair.Question: What are the symptoms of Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) ?
QAPair.Answer: Symptoms may include: Chills, Fever , Back pain, Leg pain , Abdominal pain , Headache , General discomfort, uneasiness, or ill feeling ( malaise ), Blood in the urine (red urine) ,

QAPair.Question: How to diagnose Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) ?
QAPair.Answer: Laboratory tests can help diagnose this condition. Bilirubin levels are high in blood and urine., Complete blood count (CBC) shows anemia., Coombs test is negative., Donath-Landsteiner test is positive., Lactate dehydrogenase level is high. ,

QAPair.Question: What are the treatments for Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) ?
QAPair.Answer: Treating the underlying condition can help. For example, if PCH is caused by syphilis, symptoms may get better when the syphilis is treated. In some cases, medicines that suppress the immune system are used.

QAPair.Question: What is the outlook for Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) ?
QAPair.Answer: People with this disease often get better quickly and do not have symptoms between episodes. In most cases, the attacks end as soon as the damaged cells stop moving through the body.

QAPair.Question: What are the complications of Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) ?
QAPair.Answer: Complications may include: Continued attacks, Kidney failure, Severe anemia ,

Question.qtype: when to contact a medical professional

QAPair.Question: Do I need to see a doctor for Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) ?
QAPair.Answer: Contact your health care provider if you have symptoms of this disorder. The provider can rule out other causes of the symptoms and decide whether you need treatment.

QAPair.Question: How to prevent Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) ?
QAPair.Answer: People who have been diagnosed with this disease can prevent future attacks by staying out of the cold.
